title: 111_hr1745
content: The "Family Health Care Accessibility Act of 2010" provides liability protections for health professional volunteers at community health centers. The "Family Health Care Accessibility Act of 2010" offers liability protections for health professional volunteers at community health centers. Section 224 of the Public Health Service Act now deems health professional volunteers at specified entities as employees of the Public Health Service when providing eligible services to individuals. The "Family Health Care Accessibility Act of 2010" provides liability protections for health professional volunteers at community health centers. Health care practitioners sponsored by entities described in subsection (g)(4) can provide services without compensation from individuals or third-party payers, except for reasonable expenses reimbursed by the entity. The "Family Health Care Accessibility Act of 2010" offers liability protections for health professional volunteers at community health centers. Practitioners must post a notice of limited liability and be licensed or certified to provide services. The Act applies certain subsections to health care practitioners sponsored by specified entities. The "Family Health Care Accessibility Act of 2010" provides liability protections for health professional volunteers at community health centers. To be considered a health professional volunteer, a health care practitioner must be sponsored by the entity and deemed an employee of the Public Health Service by the Secretary. The liability protections under the "Family Health Care Accessibility Act of 2010" apply to health care practitioners deemed employees of the Public Health Service by the Secretary. The Act also specifies conditions that must be met for health care practitioners providing services as volunteers at community health centers. The fund established under subsection (k)(2) can be transferred for carrying out this subsection. The Attorney General, in consultation with the Secretary, must submit a report to Congress by May 1 each fiscal year estimating the amount of claims to be paid for acts or omissions of health professional volunteers. The Secretary must transfer funds to Treasury accounts annually by December 31. The subsection takes effect on October 1, 2011, with provisions for regulations and reports submission to Congress. The House of Representatives passed the bill on September 23, 2010. Attest: LORRAINE C. MILLER, Clerk.
